abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on the
            quality of education in Malawi. Malawi’s poverty reduction
            strategies identified the enhancement of human capital as
            one of Malawi's formidable challenges. In response to
            these challenges, the International Development
            Association’s approach included training of primary school
            teachers, provision of materials to secondary teachers and
            training of university lecturers at various levels. The
            project engaged the communities through the participation of
            parent-teacher associations in the procurement of learning
            materials, organization of school feeding programs, and
            promotion of good health and nutrition practices. As a
            result, children were reached with interventions, which
            included distribution of Vitamin A and iron, folic acid,
            de-worming, treatment of malaria and fever, and promotion of
            good health and nutrition practices.  The project improved
            learning through supply of basic learning materials to
            schools while strengthening the participation of communities
            in school management. At the primary level a new training
            college was constructed for primary teachers to increase the
            number of trained teachers annually. Finally, the project
            supported the development of a better policy framework and
            more comprehensive strategic plan
